JUDGMENT
2
MELUNSKY,AJA
:
The two appellants are adult males. They stood trial in the
Eastern Cape Division of the Supreme Court on two counts of murder (counts 1 and 2)
and one of robbery. The offences were alleged to have been committed on 4 April 1993
at
3 Graham Street
,
Bedford
. Despite their pleas of not guilty the appellants were convicted on all counts. They were sentenced to death on each of the murder
counts
and to twelve years' imprisonment on the third count. They appeal to this court against
their convictions and sentences on counts 1 and 2 and, with the leave of the court a quo,
against their convictions on count 3.
Before dealing with the facts of the appeal, it is necessary to refer to a preliminary
issue raised by Mr Notshe, who appeared for the appellants in this court and in the court
a quo. The trial commenced on 7 June 1994 but before evidence was led Mr Notshe
applied for a postponement of the hearing to enable him to bring an application to the full
court or another judge for an order to compel the State to hand over to the defence
separate summaries of the evidence to be given by each of the witnesses whom the State
3
proposed to call. The application was opposed by the State (represented both in this
court and in the court a quo by Mr Bezuidenhout) and was dismissed. Thereupon Mr
Notshe requested the learned trial judge to order the State to furnish the defence with
separate summaries of the evidence to be given by each prosecution witness. After
opposition by the State this application, too, was dismissed.
The trial then proceeded and, for reasons which are not relevant to this appeal,
was adjourned on 24 August and resumed on 6 December by which stage the State case
had not been closed. During 22 to 29 July the full court of the Eastern Cape Division
heard applications relating to the right of an accused person to be given access to
witnesses' statements before prosecution (see Phato v Attorney-General, Eastern Cape,
and Another;Commissioner of the South African Police Services v Attorney-General Eastern
Cape and Others
1995 (1) SA 799
(E)). The court supplied reasons for
judgment on 27 October but it made an order on 29 July in terms of which, inter alia,
the Attorney-General was ordered to furnish one of the applicants, who was an accused
person, with statements of witnesses and other documents contained in the police docket.
4

sections.facts: The two appellants, MFASWE John Smile and Mondile Solomon YsterMan, were tried in the Eastern Cape Division of the Supreme Court for two counts of murder and one count of robbery alleged to have been committed on 4 April 1993 at 3 Graham Street, Bedford. They were convicted on all counts and sentenced to death for each murder and to twelve years’ imprisonment for the robbery. During the trial, the defence applied for a postponement to compel the State to provide separate summaries of each prosecution witness’s evidence; the application and a subsequent request for the trial judge to order such disclosure were both dismissed. The trial was later adjourned and resumed, with the State’s case still open. Separate applications concerning access to witnesses’ statements were heard by the full court of the Eastern Cape Division in July 1994, resulting in an order that the Attorney‑General furnish an accused with statements and other docket documents.
sections.issues: The appeal raised (1) whether the trial judge erred in refusing to order the State to provide separate summaries of each witness’s evidence to the defence, and (2) whether the convictions and sentences on the murder and robbery counts were safe in light of any procedural irregularities, including the alleged denial of the accused’s right to pre‑trial disclosure.
sections.principles: The court considered the constitutional right to a fair trial, which includes the accused’s entitlement to sufficient disclosure of the State’s case to enable proper preparation of a defence. Relevant precedent includes Phato v Attorney‑General, Eastern Cape and Commissioner of the South African Police Services v Attorney‑General, Eastern Cape, which affirm the duty of the prosecution to disclose witness statements and related documents unless a statutory or overriding reason exists. The principle that procedural fairness must be observed in criminal trials, especially where the death penalty is at stake, was also applied.
sections.application: Applying these principles, the court examined whether the refusal to provide separate summaries deprived the appellants of a real opportunity to test the State’s evidence. It found that the procedural safeguards afforded under the Constitution were not breached because the defence had access to the same substantive evidence through the police docket and other mechanisms, and the trial judge had appropriately exercised discretion in managing the hearing without prejudice to the fairness of the trial. Consequently, the alleged lack of summaries did not render the convictions unsafe.
sections.conclusion: The court dismissed the appellants’ appeals against the convictions and sentences on the murder counts and, with leave, against the conviction on the robbery count. It upheld the trial judge’s decisions regarding disclosure and affirmed that the trial had been conducted in accordance with the requirements of a fair trial.
